properties.name: 18/06/07 - Family devastated at sentence for attacker who left man paralysed
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE sisters of a man paralysed in a horrific knife attack at the hands of his partner\'s former husband say it is he who has been given a life sentence after his attacker was jailed. But victim Stephen Parry, who is now confined to a wheelchair, says his attacker, Anthony Charles Stephen, who was locked up indefinitely on Friday, has taken enough out his life and is not going to take any more. It later became clear that his attacker could be released in six years. In an interview with the Leader, they said that whatever sentence the knifeman received, it would never be enough for what he has done. The 54-year-old attacker from Rayon Road, Greenfield, near Holywell, admitted attempted murder on Friday and was given an indeterminate sentence at Mold Crown Court. Mr Parry, 45, is still undergoing treatment at the spinal injuries unit at Southport General Hospital, where partner Karen, the defendant\'s former wife, is constantly at his side. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961697

properties.name: 18/06/07 - Jobs axed at Wrexham firm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWORKERS at a pharmaceuticals factory have been rocked after being told 92 of them are to lose their jobs. Wockhardt UK, based on Wrexham Industrial Estate, plans to cut staff in two phases, with 42 set to go in August, and the remainder in March next year. The plant employs 395 people, making tablets, ointments and sterile products for international customers. According to bosses, the cuts have been forced on them by changes to the industry picture and competition from rivals who have switched production to countries where labour is cheaper. Wockhardt managing director Sirjiwan Singh told the Evening Leader he was disappointed at having to make the decision. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961266

properties.name: 18/06/07 - Wrexham couple celebrate lottery win
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA YOUNG couple who are getting married next year now plan to do it in style after scooping a lottery windfall. Becky Williams and Chris Robertson, who both work at Airbus in Broughton and live in Caego, Wrexham, matched five numbers plus the bonus ball in the Lotto draw on Saturday, June 9, and won £164,028. Planner Becky, who picks the same numbers each week based on a combination of birthdays, recognised the digits when she checked the numbers on Sunday morning. "I was on the phone to my sister last week, talking about the cost of the wedding," said the 25-year-old. "I said to her \'Never mind, I\'m going to win the lottery on Saturday!\' Now it has actually happened I can\'t believe it." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2961210

properties.name: 19/06/07 - 11-year-old terrorised by gang for being disabled
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM mother says she and her disabled son are living in fear of children as young as seven who are making their lives a misery. Lisa Behrendt, 30, says she and 11-year-old Liam have been terrorised for months by a gang who mercilessly abuse and threaten them. Liam has scoliosis of the spine and speech problems, which have made him the target of bullies for months. And the teasing has reached such a level that it makes them feel like prisoners in their own home. Lisa said: "It is horrible. At times you just feel you can\'t go outside because of what they might say. "The things people say to my son are disgusting, things that I can\'t even bring myself to repeat. We keep ourselves to ourselves and don\'t want to cause any trouble for anyone, but it seems like they just won\'t leave us alone." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963053

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Driver steered with knees as he ate spaghetti
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA LORRY driver caught steering with his knees while he ate spaghetti from a pan, has been jailed for eight weeks after he admitted dangerous driving. Martin Veens was spotted driving his left-hand 40-tonne lorry erratically on the A55, near Northop. Prestatyn magistrates heard how North Wales Police\'s helicopter camera filmed him holding and eating from a saucepan as he steered with his knees. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963587

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Fury as web sites direct people to local hotspots
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCOMMUNITY leaders have reacted furiously after various parts of Wrexham were named on the internet as hotspots for "dogging". A Leader investigation has found that websites are giving directions to sites in Johnstown, Chirk, Ruabon, Minera, Rhostyllen and Gwersyllt, guiding people looking for casual sex to areas, including rural beauty spots. According to the website Wrexham has the greatest number of "dogging" hotspots in North Wales. Among the sites singled out is the Wynnstay Woods area close to Ruabon, and local councillor Nick Colbourne said he was disgusted. He said: "This is terrible, particularly for people who live close to it. Imagine living near to that kind of thing going on. "Coincidentally, I was on the Leader website just the other day and noticed the poll on whether police should have more powers to cut back on this kind of thing. "I clicked \'yes\'. It is definitely something that should be stopped. Just to think about it happening in the area is horrible." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964046

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Mum and tot in car theft drama
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MOTHER has spoken of her anger after her car was stolen – just seconds after she had lifted her three-year-old son out of the vehicle. Paula Boyd had just taken Joshua out of his car seat when the thieves struck in broad daylight. The incident happened at 6pm on Thursday, on Station Road, Chester, opposite the Deva Mail Social Club. Paula said: "It was absolutely terrifying. I had just parked to buy some train tickets and post some letters and got Joshua out of the car, but before I could get his buggy from the boot I heard all this screaming and yelling. "Two men had taken the keys from the back seat and jumped into the car. They put the car in reverse, then drove forwards and began ramming the car in front so they could make their escape. "Another female motorist tried to block them with her car, but they got away." Paula, who lives in Upton, said she was still in shock a day later and is trying to come to terms with what happened. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2963984

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Residents pull together as torrent of water hits village
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLOODING in Hawarden caused havoc for homeowners at the weekend. Environment Agency officers, the fire service and residents of Moore Close, Hawarden, turned out in force to stop the torrent of water damaging vehicles and property. Dave Evans, 37, an estate agent who lives at Moore Close, Hawarden, which saw the worst of the flooding, said: "In some places it was 14 inches deep. "The first thing we did was phone the fire brigade. Then the Environment Agency came out and brought loads of sand bags. They were fantastic." Only last month, a national weather review showed Hawarden had one of the highest rainfalls in the country with 26.4mm. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2962009

properties.name: 19/06/07 - Stop this race crime shame
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCall for help for migrant workers as Flintshire abuse figures soar MIGRANT workers need to given more help and support to settle in Flintshire, to reduce the alarming rise in racially-motivated hate crimes. That is the view of the North Wales Race Equality Network (NWREN) who say the shocking rise in the number of hate crimes in the county can only be combated if front-line services are improved to make migrant workers feel part of the community. As the Leader exclusively reported last month, there has been a 98 per cent rise in the number of violent, racist and abusive hate crimes in Flintshire in the last 12 months. And a new report by the NWREN says there is not enough support for non-Polish migrants trying to make a new life in Flintshire. It also says fear of being abused or attacked is a major concern for migrants who feel some of the county\'s town are \'unsafe\' which limits opportunities for social inclusion in community life. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964291

properties.name: 20/06/07 - 180 jobs go at Deeside firm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWorkers at a Deeside print works are distraught after being told they are to be made redundant. Graphoprint, on Deeside Industrial Estate went into administration "out of the blue" and the 180 workers were told yesterday they were to lose jobs. The magazine and catalogue printer went into administration on Friday and today the administrators, KPMG, have announced the company will be shedding about 180 jobs. The company was declared a "phoenix from the ashes" in April, 2005 when it survived a fire which severely damaged the building and equipment. Last year Graphoprint was bought by print veteran Chris Bramley, with the backing of asset financier CIT Print and invoice discounting company Eurotracker and went on to win a number of industry awards. The Leader has been flooded with calls from workers who say they were under the impression the company, with a turnover of £27m, was in good health and that these cuts had "come out the blue". http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968020

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Breeder, 71, kept dogs in filthy, cramped conditions
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineAN ELDERLY farmer could face jail after scores of dogs and puppies were found in cold, cramped and dirty conditions on his farm. Peter Hughes, of Ashford Farm, Caeau Gleision Lane, Halkyn, kept 64 dogs in what an RSPCA inspector described as some of the worst conditions he had ever seen. He had originally pleaded not guilty to 13 charges brought by the RSPCA of causing unnecessary suffering to dogs and two charges brought by Flintshire Council\'s Environmental Health department. But yesterday at Flint Magistrates\' Court, the 71-year-old pleaded guilty to six counts of causing unnecessary suffering to border collie-type dogs, one of keeping an establishment for the breeding of dogs for which no licence had been granted, and one of breaching the licence conditions of a pet shop licence. Chris Moss, prosecuting, told the court that between September, 2005 and March, 2006 Flintshire Council received complaints from members of the public who had bought puppies from Mr Hughes. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967233

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Club's ex-steward is cleared of stealing £14,742 from employer
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA FORMER steward at Buckley Conservative Club has been cleared of stealing more than £14,000 from his employer. David William Griffiths, 47, was originally charged with stealing £2,110 from the club between June 25 and October 23, 2005, and £12,632 between October 20 and December 23 of the same year. Judge John Rogers QC, sitting at Mold Crown Court, directed the jury to find him not guilty of the first charge on the basis of insufficient evidence. A jury retired at the end of a week-long trial and cleared him of the second charge. The prosecution said the steward was responsible for banking the Buckley Conservative Club takings, but he failed to bank them properly and a shortfall emerged. When challenged and asked for the paperwork, he said he would provide it to them but never did so, said prosecutor Robert Altham. But Ben Morris, defending, told the jury Griffiths, of Donne Place, Blacon, Chester, denied any dishonesty. He had never taken any of the club\'s money and was not responsible for the shortfall. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2964892

properties.name: 20/06/07 - Disabled take to streets in fight for their rights
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline DOZENS of disabled people took part in a march through Chester to raise awareness of issues faced by people with disabilities. Disability groups from Chester and Ellesmere Port took part in the march as part of the disability charity Scope\'s Time to Get Equal Week, which aims to fight discrimination and encourage people to recognise disabled people\'s equality and human rights. Skills co-ordinator at Scope\'s skills development centre in Blacon, Mike Flood, said: "Our march is a direct challenge to the discrimination disabled people face, disablism, and the \'non-human\' way people react when they see disabled people." Scope has released research this week revealing discrimination against disabled people in Chester and the surrounding area, which shows 84 per cent of people in the North West think British society treats disabled people as second-lass citizens. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967465

properties.name: 20/06/07 - New bid to save Remploy factory
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineNEW hope could be on the horizon for disabled workers threatened with unemployment. The Leader can reveal that plans are being made to put together a consortium of local companies in a bid to save the Remploy plant on Wrexham\'s Railway Road, which employs 79 people. Last month staff were rocked by news that the furniture factory has been included in a list of 33 sites earmarked for closure in the UK. They were told that recent losses meant the plant was no longer sustainable, and that it could close by December, although a rescue could be possible if workers could show how they could keep the plant running with reduced losses. Wrexham MP Ian Lucas is now working to put together a group of businesses from the area which could keep Remploy in the town. He said: "I am very pleased with the responses I have received to date. "It is early days yet, but I have been encouraged by the positive response I have received from across the community to my ideas to save the Remploy site." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2967235

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Bank thieves caught after 110mph chase
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTWO men were captured following a high- speed car chase after a worker tipped-off police. Bernard Byrne, prosecuting, told a court an employee of the Royal Bank of Scotland, in Union Street, Chester, looked out the window at about 7pm one Monday and saw two men outside. Suspicious about their reason for being there, the worker noted their car registration number. A short time later the worker noticed a 42in plasma television was missing from the premises, and assumed the men had taken it. Police were called and the car containing the two men was located travelling along the M53. The driver then accelerated onto the M56 doing speeds of up to 110mph. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2972171

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Dozen patients get breast cancer drug
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline WREXHAM Maelor Hospital has so far provided 12 patients with the breast cancer drug, Herceptin. Hospital bosses say that since the drug was first offered to patients in Wrexham early last year, everyone who has needed it has been given it. Eight of the women who have received Herceptin are new patients. The total cost of prescribing the drug so far is £175,000. North East Wales NHS Trust spokesman Andrew Scotson said: "That is being funded by the Local Health Board. "It needs to be allocated from other areas, or savings need to be found elsewhere, to fund this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968108

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Focus on animals which braved wartime horrors
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineThe bravery of animals during wartime will be highlighted at a talk next week. David Hopkins, co-curator of The Animals\' War exhibition at the Imperial War Museum North (May 26 to January 8), will enlighten visitors to the Grosvenor Museum in Chester about animals in conflict, from the First World War to the present day. Visitors can find out about cavalry horses, mules, elephants, camels, horses and other creatures that have transported soldiers and equipment; the pigeons and dogs who have carried messages; the dogs that have guarded military personnel and property, located injured soldiers, tracked the enemy and sniffed-out explosives, and the animals adopted as official and unofficial mascots and pets by the military. The talk is also a reunion opportunity for members of the Cheshire and North Wales Evacuee Reunion Group and runs from 2-3pm in the museum\'s lecture theatre. Tickets priced £4 (£3 concessions) can be bought from Chester History and Heritage staff on 01244 402110. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971117

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Support floods in for printers devastated by jobs axe
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineMESSAGES of support have been flooding in for the families of workers left devastated by major job cuts at a Deeside firm. As the Leader revealed yesterday, about 180 workers at print company Graphoprint, on the Deeside Industrial Estate, have been made redundant after the magazine and catalogue printer went into administration due to financial problems. The company survived a fire in April, 2005 which severely damaged their equipment and premises and last year was bought by print veteran Chris Bramley, with the backing of asset financier CIT Print and invoice discounting company Eurotracker. Administrators KPMG are now seeking a buyer for the company while workers have been told there will be no redundancy payments. One worker, who had been with the company for 20 years, told the Leader: "They must have known the company was in trouble. Why didn\'t they let us know earlier? We\'re not even going to get paid for the last month we have worked. "There\'s guys here like me who have been with this company decades and the way we are being treated is disgraceful. Families are being devastated by this." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971546

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Support the zoo's dragons and win an exclusive tour
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER ZOO is giving its loyal supporters a chance to perform a small miracle and win an exclusive behind the scenes tour. The zoo, a conservation charity with over 7,000 animals, is asking its supporters to back its important conservation work through its Small Miracles appeal – and in exchange they will be entered into a prize draw for a behind the scenes tour. The tour will include a special look at Islands in Danger, which is home to the zoo\'s two female Komodo Dragons, Flora and Nessie, and five baby dragons. Flora became an overnight star when she laid a clutch of fertile eggs despite never being mixed with, or mated by, a male dragon. This groundbreaking work with Komodo Dragons is just one of the ways Chester Zoo undertakes its conservation work. The zoo works with over 500 different endangered species, both at home in Chester and in more than 40 countries around the world. Kevin Buley, Chester Zoo\'s Curator of Lower Vertebrates and Invertebrates, said: "None of this work we do would be possible without the support of our visitors and supporters. As a charity we rely on voluntary contributions from people who care about animals to fund our vital work." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2968132

properties.name: 21/06/07 - Town's teen abortion rate shock
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineWREXHAM has one of the highest percentages of teenage abortions in Wales, new figures reveal. According to statistics from the Department of Health, more than one abortion a day was carried out in the county borough last year, with 11.8 per cent of them on under-18s. The rate is higher than in many other parts of Wales, and the total number of abortions carried out on women from the Wrexham area is the second-highest in North Wales. The number of abortions carried out on under 18s in Wrexham was higher than those in Cardiff (8 per cent), Swansea (11.6 per cent), Denbighshire (11 per cent) and Flintshire (11.3 per cent). Conwy was named as having the highest number with more than 15 per cent of the total number of abortions being carried out on under 18s. The figures show the overall number of abortions rose in England and Wales from 186,416 in 2005, to 193,737 last year, a rise of nearly four per cent. The previous year, the figures had risen by just 0.4 per cent. Across Wales, 11 per cent of abortions took place at more than 13 weeks into the pregnancy. In this area, Wrexham\'s figures are particularly worrying, according to experts. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2971996

properties.name: 22/06/07 - Brunstrom's delight as everyone arrives alive
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineFLINTSHIRE has been singled out for high praise from controversial North Wales Chief Constable Richard Brunstrom, after he revealed there had been no deaths on the county\'s roads in the past year. That is a massive turnaround for the county, which just last year was condemned as having some of the deadliest roads in Wales. A report published by the Wales Centre for Health last summer deemed Flintshire among the worst counties in Wales for road deaths, with the eighth highest number of deaths on its roads, at seven per 100,000. Figures showed in 2004, 62 people were killed or injured on roads in the county, including drivers, passengers and pedestrians. Of these, 26 were under the age of 25. In 2005 eight people died on the county\'s roads, four of whom were males aged 25 and under. In his online blog Mr Brunstrom said with no deaths recorded in the past 12 months, Flintshire and its councillors deserve high praise for cutting out fatalities and that it proved the Arrive Alive partnership, which has had its critics, is proving successful. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2975766

properties.name: 22/06/07 - Man's £15,000 Maelor butty scam
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA MAN who fleeced a Wrexham Maelor Hospital charity to the tune of £15,000 has escaped going to jail. Peter Anderson, 48, (pictured) supplied sandwiches to a charity which raises funds by running five cafes for patients and visitors. But he over-charged Maelor Voluntary Services by 100 per cent, Mold Crown Court was told. Judge Dafydd Hughes told Anderson it had been a mean, carefully calculated fraud on a charitable organisation. He had deprived the charity of money which would have been used for the benefit of sick patients. Anderson, of Radmore Road, Liverpool, admitted 15 charges of obtaining money transfers by deception and received a suspended 51-week prison sentence, and was ordered to carry out 150 hours of unpaid work. He produced a banker\'s draft in court to repay the whole £15,000 and now a specialist financial probe into his affairs will be held so a hearing under the Proceeds of Crime Act can take place in September. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2975617
